oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Isaac Litton High School Marching Band performing at the "Sergeant York" premiere

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Motion picture premieres; Motion picture theaters; Theaters; Hotels; Spectators; People
York, Alvin Cullum, 1887-1964; Sergeant York (Motion picture); Hermitage Hotel (Nashville, Tenn.); Knickerbocker Theatre (Nashville, Tenn.); Storer, Walter Henry, 1898-1974
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Isaac Litton High School Marching Band performs on 6th Avenue outside the Knickerbocker Theatre and the Hermitage Hotel on the occasion of the Nashville premiere of the film "Sergeant York."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Storer, Walter Henry, 1898-1974
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Dr. Walter H. Storer Photograph Collection, ca. 1930-1955
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Warner Brothers producer Jesse Lasky had sought to secure movie rights to the York story since 1919. York finally relented around 1940 when Lasky argued that Americans needed inspiration in light of the war in Europe. The film became the highest-grossing movie of 1941 and was nominated for eleven Oscars.
